Sure! Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words, while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

A devastating landslide in the Tibet Autonomous Region buried 83 workers from Tibet Huatailong Mining Development Co. Ltd., a subsidiary of China National Gold Group Corp., on Friday morning. The incident occurred around 6 a.m. in Maizhokunggar County, east of Lhasa, and was made up of about 2 million cubic meters of mud, rock, and other debris. The victims included two Tibetans.

Sure! Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

The United States and Libya held face-to-face talks in Tunisia, with the sole purpose of the meeting being for the US to demand that Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi "must go". The US official stated that the meeting was not the start of negotiations, but rather a one-time message to convey that Gadhafi's regime must end. The Libyan government spokesman welcomed further steps and stated that the meeting was a first step towards resolving the conflict. The US has been bombing Libya under a UN mandate to protect civilians from troops loyal to Gadhafi.

Sure! Here is a summary of the story in under 150 words while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

Canada has officially renounced the Kyoto Protocol, citing unworkable goals without the participation of the United States and China. The Environment Minister, Peter Kent, stated that Canada will continue to work towards reducing greenhouse gas emissions, but the self-imposed goal of 17% reduction by 2020 is well below the Kyoto targets. The previous government signed onto the treaty without regard to its fulfillment, resulting in financial penalties equivalent to $1,600 per family. The government's decision comes after international negotiators agreed to extend the treaty's limits on carbon emissions.

Sure! Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words, while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

Faezeh Hashemi, daughter of former Iranian president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, has been sentenced to six months in prison for participating in anti-government protests. She was arrested last year and will serve her sentence in Evin prison's security unit, which is a relatively comfortable section of the prison. Her father, a powerful cleric and former parliament speaker, has been a vocal critic of the government and its violent crackdown on the opposition movement. Despite toning down his attacks, he remains one of the government's most politically powerful men in Iran.

Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words, while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

Colton Harris-Moore, known as the "Barefoot Bandit," pleaded not guilty to six federal charges, but his lawyer said a draft of a plea agreement could be finished by the end of the day. Harris-Moore is accused of stealing boats, cars, and planes while eluding police capture, and he faces up to 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. His lawyer stated that any money generated from possible book or movie deals will go to the victims. Harris-Moore limped into court, but his lawyer attributed the limp to an injury sustained during a volleyball game.

Sure! Here is the story summarized in less than 150 words while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

A US Marine, Cpl. Trent D. Thomas, was found guilty of conspiracy to commit murder and other charges for his role in the death of an Iraqi civilian in 2006. He will be demoted to the rank of entry-level private and receive a bad-conduct discharge. The 25-year-old Marine was part of a group of Marines who were accused of dragging the victim from his home and shooting him in the street. The group's leader, Sgt. Lawrence G. Hutchins III, has pleaded not guilty to murder and conspiracy charges and faces a sentence of life in prison if convicted. Thomas initially pleaded guilty but has since changed his plea to not guilty, arguing that he was following orders.

Sure! Here is the story summarized in under 150 words while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

A poultry facility in Missouri has been quarantined after a suspected case of bird flu was discovered during routine testing. The facility, which is owned by Cargill Corp., will euthanize up to 15,000 younger birds exposed to older turkeys that tested positive for bird flu antibodies. The older birds will be harvested at another location with no health risk. The state says it is extremely rare for humans to be affected by this type of bird flu. The facility is under quarantine while the investigation continues, and the USDA is monitoring the situation.

Sure! Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

A mayoral candidate in Paris has proposed transforming the city's disused metro stations into vibrant spaces, such as swimming pools, nightclubs, and art installations. The candidate, Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet, has commissioned illustrations showcasing the possibilities for the stations, including one called Arsenal, which could be converted into a theater and a restaurant. The proposal is part of Kosciusko-Morizet's campaign to revitalize the city's underground spaces. However, the candidate still lags behind in the mayoral race, so the future of the proposals remains uncertain.

Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words, while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

David Headley, born Daood Gilani, was sentenced to 35 years in prison for his role in the 2008 Mumbai attacks that killed 164 people, including six U.S. citizens. He had changed his name to David Headley in 2006 to present himself as an American without Muslim or Pakistani ties. He admitted to conducting advance surveillance for the operation in India and cooperated with U.S. authorities, leading to his recommendation for a lenter sentence. The Indian government wants to conduct another trial for Headley, but the U.S. government has said it will not send him to any other country.

Egyptian President Mohamed Morsy has condemned a deadly attack on soldiers at an army checkpoint in Sinai, promising to capture those responsible. At least 15 soldiers were killed and 9 others wounded when masked assailants attacked the checkpoint during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan. The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) blamed terrorists associated with the Global Jihad group for the violence. The Rafah border crossing has been closed indefinitely, and military forces have been deployed to assist. Morsy assured that the Sinai is safe and under control, and called for an emergency meeting of the military council. Hamas condemned the attack, closing all border tunnels connecting Gaza with Egypt.

Sure! Here is the story summarized in less than 150 words while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

At least four people were killed in a bomb blast in Kano, Nigeria, on Sunday. The explosion occurred at a busy intersection in a predominantly Christian area and left several cars burning. Police have cordoned off the area and are searching for suspects and any additional bombs. The identity of those responsible for the attack is unknown, and it is not clear if it is related to the recent abduction of more than 200 girls by Boko Haram. Terrorism in Nigeria has been in the global spotlight recently due to the ongoing crisis.

Sure! Here is the story in less than 150 words, with high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

NASA's Space Shuttle Discovery is set to launch next week on a mission to the International Space Station. The shuttle will carry a crew of seven astronauts, including Nicole Stott, who will remain on the space station as a flight engineer. The mission will also deliver a new treadmill, named COLBERT, which was named for comedian Stephen Colbert after an online poll. The treadmill will help astronauts stay fit in space. The launch is scheduled for 1:36 a.m. ET on Tuesday, but delays may occur due to weather or technical issues.

Six unidentified men were found hidden in a cargo truck during a random security sweep at Atlanta's Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport. The men were handed over to federal agencies, and it was discovered that they were illegal immigrants from Mexico and El Salvador. The investigation is ongoing, and it is believed that the men did not have any ill intent against the United States. The men were found during a security exercise that was part of a routine operation carried out at various transportation hubs.

Lt. Gen. Karl Eikenberry, a career military officer, has been nominated as the next U.S. Ambassador to Afghanistan. If approved, he hopes to bring his wife, Ching Eikenberry, with him to the country. However, the State Department designates Afghanistan as an "unaccompanied post" due to security concerns, which means family members are not allowed. Senator John Kerry, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, supports the idea of Eikenberry bringing his wife to the Embassy, but there is no immediate reaction from the State Department.

Sure! Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words, while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

First Lady Michelle Obama will campaign in Iowa next month to support Democratic candidate Bruce Braley in one of the closest Senate races of the 2014 midterms. This is only her second announced appearance on the trail for a candidate, and she may inject momentum into a tight race. Braley is running against Republican state Sen. Joni Ernst, who has gained popularity with endorsements from well-known Republicans and a popular ad campaign. The first lady's appearance may be seen as a boost for Braley, as her husband's low approval ratings in Iowa may not be a help for his campaign. Other popular Democrats, such as Bill and Hillary Clinton, will also appear in Iowa this weekend.

Sure! Here is a summary of the story in under 150 words, while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

Anes Subasic, a naturalized US citizen from Bosnia, was found guilty of terrorism charges, including conspiracy to murder, kidnap, and injure people overseas. He was also convicted of providing material support to terrorists. Subasic is the seventh member of a North Carolina group convicted of terror activities, and he will face up to life in prison at sentencing in August. According to the government, Subasic and others worked to provide money, weapons training, transportation, and personnel to advance violent jihad.

Sure! Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words, while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

Christine Rougoor, a 25-year-old woman from Ontario, Canada, recently went bungee jumping over an icy river in Whistler, British Columbia, while seated in her wheelchair. The adventure, which she won through a charity contest, was organized by 9Lives Adventures, a company that specializes in helping people with disabilities achieve their extreme sports dreams. Rougoor, who has been paralyzed since a motocross accident in 2008, found the experience to be liberating and would encourage others with disabilities to take the leap.

Here's the story in under 150 words, with high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

The 2014 midterm elections brought historic victories for Republicans and individual milestones. Tim Scott, an African-American from the South, became the first black Senator since Reconstruction. Joni Ernst, a female combat veteran, broke the glass ceiling in the Senate. Shelley Moore Capito became the first woman elected from West Virginia. Tom Cotton, an Iraq War veteran, was elected to the Senate. The election also marked the first time in U.S. history that there will be 100 women in Congress. Gina Raimondo became Rhode Island's first female governor. Elise Stefanik, at 30, became the youngest woman elected to Congress. These individuals made history, while also contributing to the Republican Party's strong showing.

Here's the story summarized in under 150 words, preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

In western Afghanistan, a helicopter crash killed 10 Americans, including seven U.S. service members and three U.S. civilians, on Monday. The cause of the crash was low visibility due to thick dust, according to the U.S. Army. The crash occurred during a successful operation to disrupt arms smuggling and narcotics trafficking. Two other NATO service members were injured. No enemy fire was involved in either of the two crashes that occurred on Monday, the largest single-day loss of American lives in Afghanistan in four years.

Sure! Here's the story in under 150 words while preserving coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

Candace Eloph, from Shreveport, Louisiana, had been searching for her half-brother for years, after her mother gave him up for adoption in 1977. Unexpectedly, she found him living across the street - Jamie Wheat. Their mothers, Joellen Cottrell and Ann Wheat, took a DNA test, confirming their relation with a 99.995% probability. Wheat's adoptive parents embraced the news, and the family is now reunited, excited to make up for lost time. This reunion brings a new beginning for all, with a sense of lifted weight and a fresh start.

Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words, while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

In a Red Chair interview with CNN, George Clinton, the 70-year-old architect of P-Funk, shares the secret to his longence. He reflects on his numerous band mates throughout the years, crediting them for his success. Clinton also talks about the importance of his music and fans, and how they have kept him going. He fights to protect artists' work and advises others wanting to get into the business to not abuse drugs. Despite some decades of making better decisions, Clinton is healthy, has energy, and hopes to do what he loves best for years to come.

Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands will abdicate on April 30, her 33rd anniversary of her coronation, and hand the throne to her son Prince Willem-Alexander. In a televised speech, she assured the Dutch people that she will still be involved and thanked them for their faith in her. She has reigned for 33 years and has three children with her late husband, Prince Claus. Prince Willem-Alexander is fully prepared to take the throne and will serve the country with devotion. The Queen turns 75 on Thursday.

Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

Prominent Texas attorney Marco Antonio Delgado was arrested and charged with laundering over $600 million for a Mexican drug cartel. Delgado, a former university trustee, faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted. Despite his legal troubles, he had been active in the local community, donating to the El Paso Symphony Orchestra and setting up a scholarship for Latino students at Carnegie Mellon University. His lawyer claims he is innocent, and the case highlights the serious nature of money laundering charges and the impact they can have on those involved.

Venezuelan state television broadcast images of Simon Bolivar's exhumed skeleton, as President Hugo Chavez suspects the former military leader was murdered. Chavez has described Bolivar, who died in 1830, as "the father of the revolution" and credited him with liberating several Latin American nations. DNA tests will be performed on the remains and clothing items found in the tomb to determine if he was poisoned or killed by another means. The broadcast faded to black, showing Chavez singing along to the national anthem.

Here is a summary of the story in less than 150 words, while preserving high coherence, consistency, fluency, and relevance:

At least four people were killed and nine injured in clashes in Saudi Arabia's Qatif region. The violence began as protests demanding the government release Shiite prisoners and grant more rights, and escalated with gunfire breaking out during a funeral procession. The Interior Ministry attributed the violence to "unknown criminal sources" and blamed "foreign masters" for instigating the unrest. The protests come amid tension between Iran, a predominantly Shiite nation, and the Sunni world.

A wildfire in Michigan's Upper Peninsula has destroyed 97 structures, including 34 homes, a hotel, and a store. The blaze has burned over 22,000 acres since starting last week, with dry conditions exacerbating the fire danger. The Duck Lake Fire is still going despite recent rains, with crews setting up 40 miles of firelines to control the situation. The state has banned outdoor burning in 49 counties in northern Michigan to prevent further wildfires.

Zack Brown, an Ohio man, started a Kickstarter campaign to raise $10 to make potato salad for the first time. Despite his lack of experience and vague recipe, his campaign gained traction and raised nearly $5,000 from 850 backers by Sunday evening. In return for their pledges, backers received various rewards, including a thank-you and a potato-salad themed haiku. Brown's campaign became popular due to its absurdity and mundane nature, and he plans to invite the "entire Internet" to taste his potato salad.

Kanye West demanded that all audience members stand during his concert in Sydney, threatening to stop the show if anyone remained seated. He made an exception for those with handicaps, but not everyone was able to stand, including two individuals with prosthetic limbs and wheelchairs. West clarified that only those using wheelchairs were allowed to sit, and he continued with the show after confirming that those not standing were unable to do so. The stunt received backlash on Twitter, with some criticizing West for making such demands.

The English Premier League will use the vanishing spray, a biodegradable foam that provides a visual 10-yard marker for free kicks, in the 2014/15 season. The spray, which was used at the FIFA World Cup in Brazil, was a hit with players, fans, and officials. It will make its debut in the match between Manchester United and Swansea City at Old Trafford on August 16. The Premier League consulted with both clubs and referees to implement the new technology, which has been used in Major League Soccer for several years.

A private jet crashed near Freeport, Grand Bahama, killing all nine on board. The flight originated from Nassau, and the cause of the crash is not yet clear. Andrew Young, a former U.S. ambassador to the UN, confirmed that among the victims were Myles and Ruth Munroe, the senior and co-pastor of Bahamas Faith Ministries International Fellowship. The Global Leadership Forum, which was set to begin on Monday, will continue as planned, according to Munroe's organization.

The U.S. Open will finally get retractable roofs over its two main stadiums, bringing an end to weather-related woes. Arthur Ashe Stadium, which seats 22,500 fans, will have a roof by 2017, with a more realistic forecast by 2016. Louis Armstrong Stadium will also get a retractable roof by 2018. The overall cost of the project is expected to hit $550 million. This development comes after years of delays due to technological and engineering advances making the work possible. Player reactions have been positive, with Serena Williams welcoming the news that likely means no more Monday finals. Jo-Wilfried Tsonga has pulled out of this year's tournament due to a knee injury.

The China National Gold Group Corp.'s subsidiary, Tibet Huatailong Mining Development Co. Ltd., was affected by the tragedy.

The United States and Libya held face-to-face talks in Tunisia, with the sole purpose of the meeting being for the US to demand that Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi "must go". The meeting was deemed a "first step" by the Libyan government, but the US official familiar with the meeting stated that it was not the start of negotiations. The US has been bombing Libya under a UN mandate to protect civilians from troops loyal to Gadhafi, who is battling a rebellion that has claimed control of the eastern half of the country. The Libyan officials had been reaching out to Washington with no response, and the US official conveyed the message that Gadhafi must go face-to-face.

The loss of a second Boeing 777 in 131 days threatens Malaysia Airlines with a potentially fatal blow, following the disappearance of Flight 370. The crash of Flight 17 in eastern Ukraine has sparked speculation that the plane may have been shot down, and the airline faces significant wreckage and loss of life. The airline's management of the crisis must be transparent and unashamed, sharing all information and data, and discussing possible mistakes. The airline's financial troubles may require a government rescue, as it has faced increased competition and lost $1.3 billion over the past three years. The crash could potentially be a fatal event for the airline, and the company must use this tragedy to redeem itself in how it deals with information and the public.

A wind turbine blade in Lincolnshire, England was destroyed, and a tabloid newspaper, The Sun, attributed the damage to a UFO. Witnesses reported seeing strange lights in the sky, and an expert suggested that the blade may have been damaged by a mechanical failure or ice. However, the Ministry of Defense has no explanation, and a UFO expert believes that the incident may be related to "balls of light" seen in the sky. The fireworks explanation was also given, as the lights were from a family celebration. The question is, was it a UFO or a simple mechanical failure?

Colton Harris-Moore, known as the "Barefoot Bandit," pleaded not guilty to six federal charges during a court appearance. His lawyer, John Henry Browne, said a draft of a plea agreement could be finished by the end of the day, and that Harris-Moore is willing to pay restitution of about $1.3 million. Browne also mentioned that Harris-Moore is in "segregation" due to an injury he sustained during a volleyball game. The trial is set for July 11.

The trial of Kaing Guek Eav, a former math teacher and prison chief of the Khmer Rouge movement, resumed in Cambodia on Monday. Prosecutors painted a grim picture of inmates who were tortured and killed under his leadership. Duch, who ran S-21 prison, where men, women, and children were shackled to iron beds and tortured before being beaten to death, faces charges of crimes against humanity, war crimes, torture, and murder. He has admitted his role in the Khmer Rouge's genocidal reign, but prosecutors say he was not just a passive observer. The trial is significant as it is the first for a former Khmer Rouge leader and sends a message that even after 35 years, justice will be served. Many Cambodians are relieved that one of the regime's former leaders is facing justice, and the trial is expected to last three or four months.

David Headley, a U.S. citizen born in Pakistan, was sentenced to 35 years in prison for his role in the 2008 Mumbai attacks that killed 164 people, including six U.S. citizens. Headley changed his name from Daood Gilani to facilitate his surveillance in India, and he cooperated with U.S. authorities in investigating terror plots. He received a Social Security number in Pennsylvania in the late 1970s and attended terrorism training camps in Pakistan. The Indian government wants to conduct another trial for Headley, but the U.S. government has said it will not send him to any other country. Prosecutors noted that his cooperation has provided valuable intelligence about terrorist activities.

Egyptian President Mohamed Morsy has condemned a deadly attack on soldiers at an army checkpoint in the Sinai Peninsula, promising to capture those responsible. At least 15 soldiers were killed and 9 others wounded when masked assailants attacked the checkpoint during the breaking of the Ramadan fast. The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) blamed terrorists associated with the Global Jihad group for the violence. The attack has led to a closure of the Rafah border crossing and the deployment of additional military forces to the region. Morsy assures that Sinai is safe and fully under control, and that those responsible will pay a high price. Hamas has also condemned the attack, closing all border tunnels connecting Gaza with Egypt.

Food festivals around the world celebrate unique and unusual cuisines, from Spam in Hawaii to rocky mountain oystones in Montana. These festivals showcase the versatility of food and the creativity of chefs and vendors. Some events, like the Waikiki Spam Jam and Potato Days, feature food wrestling and mashed potato sculpting competitions. Other festivals, like the Giant Omelette Celebration in France and Switzerland's Räbechilbi Turnip Festival, highlight the cultural and historical significance of food. These festivals bring together communities and showcase the diversity of culinary traditions around the world.

The mission is scheduled to lift off at 1:36 a.m. ET Tuesday, but launches can be delayed due to inclement weather or technical concerns. The treadmill, dubbed "COLBERT," will help astronauts maintain physical fitness in space.

Google is releasing a new version of Google Glass, its wearable tech device, to current testers. The new version will work with eyeglasses and include an ear bud. Testers can invite up to three friends to join the program and buy Glass online. The new Glass is expected to go on sale to the general public next year. The current $1,500 price will still apply. The new version is expected to improve compatibility with other eyeglasses and may include hardware changes. Google Glass allows users to shoot photos, record videos, and access features like email and text messaging using voice commands. The device is part of the wearable tech movement, which is expected to be the next big wave in technology.

The men were found outside a cargo facility as part of a routine exercise carried out at various transportation hubs. They were handed over to federal agencies for processing and were not found to have any ill intent against the US. The investigation is ongoing.

The election of the next pope will be decided by 115 male cardinals, excluding the approximately 600 million Catholic women worldwide. Despite calls for women to have a greater say in the church, the idea of a female pope remains a distant dream. Historians and theologians dismiss the myth of Pope Joan, a ninth-century Englishwoman who allegedly disguised herself as a priest, as satirical fiction. However, some Catholics believe that women should have a more prominent role in the church, and female perspectives could help balance the church's hierarchical decision-making process. Despite the lack of direct representation for women in the upcoming papal election, Catholic women continue to hold important lay positions in Catholic organizations.

A Maryland man died last month after receiving a tainted organ in 2011. The donor was found to have rabies, and three other recipients in other states are being treated with anti-rabies shots. The CDC is urging doctors to test for rabies in organ donors who show encephalitis, but there is no standardized approach. The risk of transmitting rabies through an organ transplant is low, but doctors should fully inform patients of the risk.

African-American atheists exist, but are often overlooked in media representation. Many blacks identify as religious, and the church is deeply tied to tradition, history, and culture. As an atheist black woman, the author has faced ostracism from family and friends, but has found support online through the Black Nonbelievers organization. The secular community needs to acknowledge and address the lack of diverse representation, and make efforts to include people of color and other marginalized groups. While small, the growing number of visible minority atheists can lead the charge for change and recognition.

Survivors of the sunken South Korean ferry visited their high school in Ansan, where they sobbed as they walked past images of their classmates. The ferry, carrying 425 people, sank on April 16, killing at least 228 passengers and missing 74. The president of South Korea apologized for the initial response to the disaster, and investigators arrested three people for destroying evidence related to the probe. The school sent 325 students on the field trip, and scores have died at sea. The nation is in a state of grief, with the ferry's final moments captured on videos fueling fresh outrage.

BP has implemented new safety systems for offshore drilling, ahead of its competitors, following the 2010 Deepwater Horizon disaster. The UK oil group has highlighted changes such as a new monitoring unit in Houston and a training facility to teach engineers and supervisors how to manage possible leaks. BP denies gross negligence charges from the US Department of Justice and is facing debarment from new federal contracts. The company has learned from previous failures, including the Alaska pipeline leak and Texas City refinery explosion, and is focusing on safety "like a laser" to prevent future accidents.
